content:
We all "love" those clashes, where you get 100% in tests and then some validators fail. This is one of them. Validator testing one magnitude more than test cases. 

I added a test case (split the last one to two), so that the fatal inefficiency is revealed sooner than when submitted.

Minor grammar issues to fix:

it's only factor => its only factor
[] and [] is always coprime => [] and [] are always coprime

Other than these, it's ok

It is also possible to solve this without GCD. Find the smallest prime p that does not divide N (using a sieve) then return N-p
Also, all your N are square-free composite numbers. You may add some test cases with N prime or N having a square factor. Just in case someone comes with a different algorithm than yours (e.g. the one I proposed) that would be wrongly implemented.
Example : find the smallest p that does not divide N (I intentionally forgot â€™primeâ€™). 12=> p=5, returns 7. It works only because 12 is not square-free.

- 1 is a factor, added to the description to be consistent
- Modified the solution marginally to be clearer

- Added the condition that M < N outside of the constraints (one tends to overlook it in the heat of the clash)
- Since you don't want to reveal that GCD is required, I thought we could atleast mention that N-1 is coprime to N
- Added shortest mode

If these are alright with you, I'll approve :)

I think it's a bit hard for a 15 mn contest if you are not used to number theory and do not have a gcd algorithm already in code.

You have to go to wikipedia, search for Coprime integers, then understand that you have to go to the Euclidean algorithm page to solve the problem ...
Or you have to come up with a way to decompose N in prime factors...(110=2x5x11)

And also understand that  the "second largest coprime of N" is not the one starting from 1 but the one starting from N.

I would change two things :
 1) I would write "Two numbers are coprime if their gcd (greatest common divisor) is equal to 1".
 People then could faster find a gcd algorithm on google.

2)I would also write, "find M, the second largest coprime of N (starting from N-1and smaller than N)".
"Coprime of" doesn't make sense. M is the second largest integer strictly less than N which is relatively prime to N.

That seems like a much better description. I didn't understand the author's original statement.

However I am pretty sure that "a is coprime to b" is a valid phrase.

Thanks for the Pointers. I had in my mind that everyone playing in clash of code had, at least once, did a GCD function so I was sure it will be easy.

Also, for [1] I intentionally didn't include the GCD in the explanation and twisted it a bit so that the players will be forced to think deeper.

For [2] I wrote it like that intentionally so as to show that M is a real number, though maybe showing that M<N is enough.

I'll try and take your words into consideration. Thanks again.
I believe it's true because for any number N, the largest coprime is N-1, so that means the second largest coprime is below N-1.
Thank you for the edit! I checked and I don't think I have any problems with it. ðŸ˜Š

OK, I misinterpreted it. Like some other comments say, the "second largest" description can be confusing. Why not put your explanation above into the statement so that all coders will understand why "second"?
